title: Zeker bezoeken, al is het maar om hen te steunen
text:
Afrika op zijn best, de “national Zoo of Gambia”, een paar hyena’s en bavianen, meer moet je niet verwachten maar dit is een unieke ervaring. Personeel is heel blij met ke komst en doet er alles aan om het naar je zij te maken. Wij waren de enige bezoekers en kregen een VIP behandeling.
Zeker eens langsgaan als je in de buurt bent!

placeInfo.name: Abuko Nature Reserve
placeInfo.address: 15 Miles South of Banjul Kombo North District, Banjul Gambia

title: Worth a visit
text: I think it was a nice walk, although it was at the end of the dry season, and at 37"C!!! We saw several vervet monkeys, the red colobus, a squirrel and an antelope, as well as several birds of all sizes. But the 1,5 litre water bottle was the best.

placeInfo.name: Abuko Nature Reserve
placeInfo.address: 15 Miles South of Banjul Kombo North District, Banjul Gambia

title: Zeer slechte ervaring
text: Geen goede ervaring. Deze uitstap zouden we zeker niet aanraden. Verwaarloosde dieren en verder niets te zien. Tijd en geldverlies.

placeInfo.name: Abuko Nature Reserve
placeInfo.address: 15 Miles South of Banjul Kombo North District, Banjul Gambia

title: Enttaeuschung
text:
Lieblos gestalteter Nationalpark in der Nähe von Banjuel. Die Rastplaetze wurden sicherlich seit Jahren nicht mehr angeschaut, beim Krokodil Teich funktiioniert das Fernglas nicht, die dortige Ausstellung ist eine Zumutung. 
Es waere ein Fortschritt wenn zumindest ein Mal am Tag der Abfall aufgeraeumt wuerde. 
Mitarbeiter gaebe es genug, auch zwei westliche Mitarbeiter. Aber die macten wohl lieber einen Sitzkreis und diskutieren als zu handeln wie wir gesehen haben.  
Es gibt aber zumindest etliche interessante Voegel und einige Affen zu bewundern.

placeInfo.name: Abuko Nature Reserve
placeInfo.address: 15 Miles South of Banjul Kombo North District, Banjul Gambia

title: Enjoy This Fun Friendly Farm Walk
text:
The cattle market proved an interesting experience in culture and animal knowledge. Our wise local guide pointed out three types of cattle, from Sénégal, Mali, and The Gambia. Soon we were able to distinguish the breeds.  He gave us info on likely trading prices and the keys to pricing cattle. We also strolled around sheep and goats, and had a great time taking pictures of animal antics. 
This is a great piece of a trip to The Gambia

placeInfo.name: Abuko Nature Reserve
placeInfo.address: 15 Miles South of Banjul Kombo North District, Banjul Gambia

title: Not great, pretty run down reserve
text: Not a great place to visit, there is a “museum” where they try and make you buy something to help with upkeep of the park. There aren’t too many animals there through the forest other than plenty of bugs. The zoo part had 4 sad looking hyenas, a cage full of baboons that looked they were going to break out at any minute and some slightly aggressive monkeys. Overall not great

placeInfo.name: Abuko Nature Reserve
placeInfo.address: 15 Miles South of Banjul Kombo North District, Banjul Gambia

title: Onderhouden natuurpark.
text:
Mooi en onderhouden bos waar je met een plaatselijke gids vogels kan spotten. 
Ook 1 soort wilde aapjes aanwezig welke zich gaan bijvoederen bij hun opgesloten soortgenoten.
Enkel hyena's, gieren en een opvang van een 3 tal soorten aapjes achter draad zijn eveneens te bewonderen.

placeInfo.name: Abuko Nature Reserve
placeInfo.address: 15 Miles South of Banjul Kombo North District, Banjul Gambia

title: Nature park
text: Beautiful peaceful place.  Some animals can be seen in their natural environment but you are not guaranteed to see everything as they are free to roam.  We had a guide that was very helpful and friendly and at a good price.  Staff were not pushy at all and were friendly.  Like everywhere in the Gambia you need to negotiate and know what's reasonable.  Be prepared to walk but enjoy it.

placeInfo.name: Abuko Nature Reserve
placeInfo.address: 15 Miles South of Banjul Kombo North District, Banjul Gambia

title: Vreselijke leefomstandigheden van de dieren
text: Ga niet naar dit park toe. De leefomstandigheden van de dieren zijn vreselijk. Meerdere hyena's in zeer kleine kooien. De apen moeten vechten om eten en zitten met 10 apen in een zeer klein verblijf. Al had ik dit van tevoren geweten had ik hier nooit naartoe gegaan.

placeInfo.name: Abuko Nature Reserve
placeInfo.address: 15 Miles South of Banjul Kombo North District, Banjul Gambia

title: Nothing but exploitation
text:
If you are staying at a beach resort, the drive to this place is long, bumpy and polluted.
Once there the entrance fee isn’t much - but OF COURSE you need a guide. Then they’ll try to rent you binoculars.
Our guide was nice enough but basically it’s a long walk down a path through bushes. That’s pretty much it. If you love leaves, knock yourself out.
There’s a crocodile pool where you won’t see crocodiles.
There’s an ‘education centre’ where a man will ask for maintenance donations stood next to a couple of torn posters that haven’t been replaced in 30 years. And of course, next to all this non-learning, there is an ‘opportunity’ to buy stuff you don’t want.
Then more walking until finally you get to the world’s most depressing zoo - where they’ll tell you some thoroughly unconvincing nonsense about why these baboons needed to be in an enclosure rather than just free. Clearly just an excuse to get tourists there and to have them buy peanuts to feed them with. Felt really sorry for them.
And there’s the three pens with hyenas and vultures co-existing (emphasis on ‘existing’). 
Can’t see how anyone but the most ardent fauna and bird fan (not that we saw many of those either) could get anything out of this place. Avoid and do literally anything else.

placeInfo.name: Abuko Nature Reserve
placeInfo.address: 15 Miles South of Banjul Kombo North District, Banjul Gambia

title: Ruhe mitten in der Stadt
text:
Der Eintritt kostet 35 D. Einen Guide braucht man nicht. Ich fand den Park unspektakulär. Im Prinzip geht man durch einen Wald, kommt an einem See vorbei - Krokodile habe ich nicht gesehen - und am Ende erreicht man Käfige mit Affen und Hyänen. 
Pluspunkt ist, dass er mitten in der Stadt eine ruhige Oase ist.

placeInfo.name: Abuko Nature Reserve
placeInfo.address: 15 Miles South of Banjul Kombo North District, Banjul Gambia

title: Wenig besuchter Naturpark
text: Nicht sehr groß, aber wirklich sehenswert! Vor allem abseits der Gehege beeindruckende Vogelwelt und - zu unserer Überraschung - sogar Krokodile und Buschböcke!

placeInfo.name: Abuko Nature Reserve
placeInfo.address: 15 Miles South of Banjul Kombo North District, Banjul Gambia

title: Un poco decepcionante
text: En lo que respecta a los animales, es un poco triste. Vimos un par de cocodrilos en el agua y unos cuantos monos (la mayoría en un recinto enjaulado). También había una zona con buitres y otro recinto cerrado con 3 hienas. Merece más la pena ir a ver monos al bosque de Bijilo, y los cocodrilos a Kachically.

placeInfo.name: Abuko Nature Reserve
placeInfo.address: 15 Miles South of Banjul Kombo North District, Banjul Gambia

title: Man sollte das  gesehen haben. Wenn dieses Stückchen Wald auch verbaut, dann ist es für immer verloren.
text: Es ist sehr interessant wenn man ein Nature Reserve inmitten eines Ballungsraum hat. Wenn man alleine durch wandert und ruhig ist (also ohne Guide) findet man spannende Tiere. Man braucht Zeit. Das Gehege ist für mich als Naturschützer eine Zumutung. Hab es mir gar nicht näher angesehen. Brauche sowas nicht. Die Affen verschwinden sofort wenn man näher kommt. Aber mit Zeit und Glück sieht man sie sehr nahe. Für Vögel war ich leider zu spät dran da müsste man früher so um 8 Uhr dort sein. 45 dal Eintritt. Fahrt mit Taxi je nach Verhandlung und Verkehr von Serekunda 300 - 400 je Strecke.

placeInfo.name: Abuko Nature Reserve
placeInfo.address: 15 Miles South of Banjul Kombo North District, Banjul Gambia

title: Dreadful place - just a way to con tourists. Avoid !
text:
Myself and my partner enjoy nature reserves and also sighting animals and so we believed that this would be the perfect place to visit.
We got a taxi there and the taxi driver would wait 2 hours. This was fine. It all went wrong after this! 
The park is 35D each which is fine but then they are white tourists coming and then the coming starts! Suddenly the price was 370D and forced into having a guide and paying for the taxi driver who wasn’t even joining us! Apparently it is too “dangerous” to go without a guide. Then after this rip off we had to hire binoculars for all the birds and wildlife we will be seeing. Another 100D! So far it has cost quite a lot more than expected. First impressions seem run down so I now wasn’t expecting much and was annoyed at being ripped off. What followed was a walk with a very sweaty guide with foul body odour who spoke not very good English. What I could make out was mostly about palm trees and the English man who originally founded the park just over 40 years ago. We were taken to the crocodile pool. No crocs to be seen. Disappointing. Two birds in the distance - use the expensive binoculars. Surprise, surprise they don’t work! We were then ushered into a dreadful “gift shop” selling over priced junk and almost forced to buy something. With a very poor booklet at 450D we just gave a 200D donation to get out of the room! 
After this it was a boiling hot walk through a sandy path with more nonsensical waffling from the smelly guide. We saw some monkeys in trees but this was it. The walk led (after what seemed like ages) to an abysmal excuse for a zoo. Hyenas in cages with vultures and baboons in another cage. Such cruel conditions. Some monkeys roamed around wanting to be fed which resulted in another attempt to take money from us. We refused. A man was trying to sell wooden ornaments. I didn’t even bother looking at them. Was so disappointed with this place. Luckily the guide didn’t demand a tip at the end otherwise the tip would have been - this place needs shutting down.

placeInfo.name: Abuko Nature Reserve
placeInfo.address: 15 Miles South of Banjul Kombo North District, Banjul Gambia

title: Stoffig.
text: Inderdaad wat vervallen reservaat. Stoffig pad door wat slordige!! natuur. Op het einde wat vervallen kooien met hyena en wat oude apen. Wel kun je hier iets drinken. Onderweg redelijk wat aapjes en gieren. Neem water mee en zet hoedje op.

placeInfo.name: Abuko Nature Reserve
placeInfo.address: 15 Miles South of Banjul Kombo North District, Banjul Gambia

title: Prachtig natuurgebied, aapjes krokodillen als ze thuis zijn ha ha
text:
maar vooral veel verschillen vogels en veel oude Afrikaanse zeldzame bomen..
Als je van de natuur houd, ga vooral mee.
Het is goed te belopen met eenvoudige schoenen.
Wel hoedje en drinken mee.
Onze gids babadrammeh deed het heel goed met afbeeldingen vanuit een boek.

placeInfo.name: Abuko Nature Reserve
placeInfo.address: 15 Miles South of Banjul Kombo North District, Banjul Gambia

title: Vervallen reservaat
text: Op dit moment is het zeker niet de moeite waard om het reservaat te bezoeken. Wanneer je pech hebt en niet met de taxi naar de gekooide dieren kan worden gebracht wacht je een saai zandpad van enkele kilometers. Daaraan gekomen zijn drie hyena’s, gieren en 4 bavianen te zien. Door de taxi chauffeur werd vertelt dat de overheid komend jaar ook giraffen en buffels wilde uitzetten. Hierdoor zal het “ Safari” gehalte zeker toenemen.

placeInfo.name: Abuko Nature Reserve
placeInfo.address: 15 Miles South of Banjul Kombo North District, Banjul Gambia

title: Isla de Naturaleza primigenia en entorno humanizado
text: Mi opinión es desde la perspectiva de un ornitólogo que busca aves. Excelente localización para observar algunas de las aves más difíciles de ver en otros lugares como los turacos violáceo y persa (de Guinéa, verde). Se necesitará todo el día para recorrerlo. Hay que pagar una cierta cantidad (poca) de dinero y se tiene la opción de contratar un guía local en la entrada.

placeInfo.name: Abuko Nature Reserve
placeInfo.address: 15 Miles South of Banjul Kombo North District, Banjul Gambia

title: A beautiful park
text: A beautiful park, the fact is that there are animals in cages but they are animals that were saved from illegal breeders.

placeInfo.name: Abuko Nature Reserve
placeInfo.address: 15 Miles South of Banjul Kombo North District, Banjul Gambia

title: Mitten im "Dschungel"
text: Mit Glück sieht man entfernt ein paar Affen. Die Affen sind nicht zutraulich. Entfernt habe ich einen blau-roten Ara gesehen und eine handgroße Spinne. Das war es ansonsten mit wilden Tieren ;). Mit Glück sieht man am Krokodilsee aber Krokodile. In der Mitte des Parks befindet sich ein Affenkäfig sowie ein Hyänenkäfig. Die Tiere waren teilweise verletzte (Rangkämpfe...) und es war allgemein eher traurig, die Tiere dort zu sehen. Einige haben auch deutliche Verhaltensstörungen gezeigt. An dieser Stelle gibt es jedoch freilebende Affen, die hier auch zutraulicher sind. Allgemein ist das ein sehr schöner Park. Besonders, wenn man gerne länger gehen möchte und ein bisschen "Abenteuer" möchte, ist man hier richtig. Wundervolle Natur!

placeInfo.name: Abuko Nature Reserve
placeInfo.address: 15 Miles South of Banjul Kombo North District, Banjul Gambia

title: Grausam
text: Ich kann hier jedem nur abraten. Für die Paar Geier lohnt es sich einfach nicht. Die Hyänen hinter Gittern, davon eine schwer verletzt, mit einer LP großen offenen Wunde auf dem Rücken, keiner kümmert sich. Die Paviane waren iin einem besch... Gehege. So etwas muss ich nicht noch unterstützen und ich kann jedem empfehlen hier nicht her zu kommen.

placeInfo.name: Abuko Nature Reserve
placeInfo.address: 15 Miles South of Banjul Kombo North District, Banjul Gambia

title: Bella riserva un po' in abbandono.
text: La riserva è bella, ottima occasione per fare una passeggiata rilassante. Però non è tanto curata e gli animali da vedere sono pochissimi. In compenso il prezzo per l'ingresso è piuttosto basso.

placeInfo.name: Abuko Nature Reserve
placeInfo.address: 15 Miles South of Banjul Kombo North District, Banjul Gambia

title: Ok for a couple of hours
text:
My wife and I love our wildlife be it birds or 4 legged animals.
The guide from our lodge took us here for the morning.
We visited the large hide and got some great sightings.
There is a shop where you can buy T shirts and other small items, also nearby is a European type toilet, which is clean(ish).
The walk through the forest was easy and most of the pathways fairly wide.
It's then that you get to see the green vervet monkeys. Most stay still long enough for a photograph.
At the end is a very sad and neglected 'zoo'.
A couple of stir crazy hyenas, an adult baboon with a couple of youngsters and some vultures.
In Europe this would have been closed down.
There is a small cafe and some very smelly toilets.

placeInfo.name: Abuko Nature Reserve
placeInfo.address: 15 Miles South of Banjul Kombo North District, Banjul Gambia

title: Leuk natuurpark
text: We zijn hier met onze gids Baxs geweest: een leuke wandeling door een junglepad naar het centrale deel met een paar apen en hyena's in kooien en een stand met Afrikaans houtsnijwerk. Onderweg een paar apen gezien. Het viel ons een beetje tegen, wellicht waren we er op het verkeerde tijdstip.

placeInfo.name: Abuko Nature Reserve
placeInfo.address: 15 Miles South of Banjul Kombo North District, Banjul Gambia

title: Ontgoochelend (maar door mijn eigen schuld).
text:
Ik bezocht Abuko nadat ik de prachtige kanotocht doorheen de mangroves bij Lamin Lodge had gemaakt. Het was dus al 11 uur voorbij, de zon stond al hoog, dus hoge temperaturen en zeer hard licht. Ik ging om de plaatselijke vogelpracht te fotograferen, maar gezien het hete moment van de dag zag ik letterlijk 2 zwaluwstaartbijeneters, een koppeltje lelielopers en een ralreiger. 
Samengevat : mijn planning en timing was zeer knudde. Aan de vele prachtige foto's op diverse internet- natuurfora te zien is Abuko fenomenaal mooi. Ik zal het bij mijn volgende bezoek aan Gambia opnieuw proberen.

placeInfo.name: Abuko Nature Reserve
placeInfo.address: 15 Miles South of Banjul Kombo North District, Banjul Gambia

title: Fascinating bird reserve
text: I last came here 8 years ago and it was the highlight of my trip to The Gambia. This time it was still wonderful but there were far fewer birds and rather more people. A good guide is essential

placeInfo.name: Abuko Nature Reserve
placeInfo.address: 15 Miles South of Banjul Kombo North District, Banjul Gambia

title: Nothing there now
text: Been before and was great. Now sadly neglected.  Only hyenas and vultures now. Still a nice walk through forest and a few monkeys to be seen if you are lucky. Only 35 dalasi  to enter and no pressure to take a guide so cannot complain.

placeInfo.name: Abuko Nature Reserve
placeInfo.address: 15 Miles South of Banjul Kombo North District, Banjul Gambia

title: Nice walk among the trees, some wildlife
text: We did the guided wlak, our guide gave some good explanations on flora & fauna. The monleys are not really wild, they expect to be fed peanuts by the tourists. But it makes for some nice pictures/video's. In the animal refuge they make the best of limited means. The hyena's seem mostly OK, I felt sorry for the monkeys behind bars though.

placeInfo.name: Abuko Nature Reserve
placeInfo.address: 15 Miles South of Banjul Kombo North District, Banjul Gambia

title: Leuk park met rustig lang pad en een boottocht langs de mangrove
text:
Ga met een gids of Simon Tours naar Abuko Park. Geen oerwoud maar wel een reservaat met apen (makaken) en prachtige vogels.
Een boottocht met lokale boot langs de mangrove is een belevenis. Mooie roeiers,aalscholvers en...de zwart witte ijsvogel !

placeInfo.name: Abuko Nature Reserve
placeInfo.address: 15 Miles South of Banjul Kombo North District, Banjul Gambia

title: Naturreservat
text: Ich bin mit grösseren Erwartungen dort hin gegangen. Die Tiere Hyänen 2 Affen und ein paar Geier waren in Käfigen,so wie in Deutschland im Zoo, nur unterr schlechteren Bedingungen. Auf dem Weg zu den Krokodilen dind uns freilebende Affen begegnet. Krokodilteich und der Weg dorthin war ok. Ansonsten nicht sehr zu empfehlen.

placeInfo.name: Abuko Nature Reserve
placeInfo.address: 15 Miles South of Banjul Kombo North District, Banjul Gambia

title: ЭКЗОТИКА!
text: В национальный парк Abuko ездили из Кололи на такси. Дорога шла внутрь материка и было интересно увидеть как и где живут гамбийцы. Как только мы вошли в лес и углубились по тропинке в чащу, меня охватил животный страх. Посетителей не было, а из непроходимых, мрачных джунглей веяло холодом, жуть... Я живо представила себе, как что нибудь ужасное сейчас выскочит, выпрыгнет или не дай Бог выползет, но если поднять голову вверх светит яркое  африканское солнце и на фоне голубого неба очень живописно смотрятся разнообразные деревья. Далее мы подошли к вольеру с гиенами. Попали в тот момент когда их кормили, и они с окровавленными мордами бегали друг за другом выхватывая добычу, а над ними... кружила стая грифов. В общем ЭКЗОТИКА, за этим мы и приехали в Гамбию. Рекомендую.

placeInfo.name: Abuko Nature Reserve
placeInfo.address: 15 Miles South of Banjul Kombo North District, Banjul Gambia

title: Intressant fågelliv
text:
Abuko Nature Reserve är väl värt ett besök för den som vill se fåglar. Guiderna är hjälpsamma och hittar många fåglar. 
Missa inte boskapsmarknaden i Abuko innan fågelskådningen.

placeInfo.name: Abuko Nature Reserve
placeInfo.address: 15 Miles South of Banjul Kombo North District, Banjul Gambia

title: Upplevelserik  utflykt
text: Ett väldigt upplevelserik utflykt som ska göras på tidiga morgon runt kl 9,00 eller efter kl 16,00 då plockar aporna nötterna ur händerna och har man tur kommer dom även att sitta på din axel eller arm. terrängen är ej handikapsvänlig efter som det finns branta backar nerför och uppför. under dagtid hamstrar bara aporna mat och ibland bara dom sitter och slappar och sover.

placeInfo.name: Abuko Nature Reserve
placeInfo.address: 15 Miles South of Banjul Kombo North District, Banjul Gambia

title: Abuko
text: Great place to visit but make sure you take water as it gets quite hot as you are walking through. The monkeys are tame, however, they can become aggressive when you are feeding them and the food runs out. Be careful with young children

placeInfo.name: Abuko Nature Reserve
placeInfo.address: 15 Miles South of Banjul Kombo North District, Banjul Gambia

title: Monkies and more monkies
text: Every where I looked I saw monkies.  We took an interesting walk in the reserve and were told about the different vegetation, the history  and the purpose of the reserve. Because I am a city girl the monkies were a delight.  For lunch we were served a delicious meal of african cuisine and entertained with african music and dance.

placeInfo.name: Abuko Nature Reserve
placeInfo.address: 15 Miles South of Banjul Kombo North District, Banjul Gambia

title: Distressed animals
text:
The reserve consists of a fairly narrow strip of land with paths meandering through it. We didn't see much bird life but it's probably there. We did see a few monkey, but not many.
Sadly the "zoo" at the far end has an air of dilapidation or down right abandonment. There are hyena incases that look distressed, one of them just lying there constantly rubbing his muzzle with his forelegs. There were no staff seen at anytime except at the entrance gate. We were glad to leave.

placeInfo.name: Abuko Nature Reserve
placeInfo.address: 15 Miles South of Banjul Kombo North District, Banjul Gambia

title: Rather sad to see.
text: A long trip for not very much.  Such a sad place - yes, there were lots of birds around, but the rewards of seeing and hearing these were more than overcome by the mangy hyaenas (in the same pen as), vultures etc.  I think in a ThirdWorld country this Reserve would be closed down forthwith.  The monkeys were interesting, the cages with reasonable labelling etc.  But, overall, don't waste your time and money.

placeInfo.name: Abuko Nature Reserve
placeInfo.address: 15 Miles South of Banjul Kombo North District, Banjul Gambia

title: A good guide is a must
text: We came here with a guide from our guesthouse, but he only guided us through some paths so we didn't see too much. The park itself is a nice place to see birds and monkeys (we saw more monkeys here than at Bijilo park), I would had liked to stay longer and with a better guide, definitely the park worth it.

placeInfo.name: Abuko Nature Reserve
placeInfo.address: 15 Miles South of Banjul Kombo North District, Banjul Gambia

title: Triste réserve
text:
Même si cette réserve propose un écrin de verdure au milieu de la ville, ce n'est malheureusement pas un endroit pour rencontrer de la faune sauvage. A la rigueur,vous y croiserez néanmoins quelques singes ici ou là. En fin de parcours, le spectacle des hyènes et des vautours en cage vous sera potentiellement peu supportable... 

Mais c'est aussi en finançant le parc avec nos visites que leurs conditions de vie pourront s'améliorer. 

Il faut y aller en visant une petite promenade au frais, sous la végétation, rien de plus.

placeInfo.name: Abuko Nature Reserve
placeInfo.address: 15 Miles South of Banjul Kombo North District, Banjul Gambia

title: Birds galore!
text: We visited this nature reserve as part of a birding holiday in The Gambia. We had our own birdguide, Mas Sangeng, arranged by Farakunku Lodges where we were based, however there are guides available to hire at the reserve. Our guide was excellent and we would not have seen half the birds and wildlife without him. The area around the crocodile pool was a bit noisey, some boats were being taken on to the pond and this disturbed any birds there. Green Vervet Monkeys played around the benches and seemed used to visitors. It was further along the pathways we started to encounter the more interesting birds,  Green and Violet Turaco, Western Bluebill and African Paradise Flycatcher to name just a few.  With patience and a good guide the possibilities are endless.  We had no interest in visiting the "zoo" preferring to spend our time looking for birds and we were not disappointed.

placeInfo.name: Abuko Nature Reserve
placeInfo.address: 15 Miles South of Banjul Kombo North District, Banjul Gambia

title: Niet veel gezien
text:
Bezocht en doorgelopen. Veel dieren gehoord maar niet gezien tot mijn man de zipper van de rugtas bewoog. Daar waren de apen.
Wij  persoonlijk hadden het liever overgeslagen in onze tour.
Gelopen zonder gids.

placeInfo.name: Abuko Nature Reserve
placeInfo.address: 15 Miles South of Banjul Kombo North District, Banjul Gambia

title: Zo gaaf...zoveel apen in een mooi park
text: Super was weliswaar in 2014......Heel goedkoop. Met onze gids de leukste paadjes..zodat we de apen veel zagen

placeInfo.name: Abuko Nature Reserve
placeInfo.address: 15 Miles South of Banjul Kombo North District, Banjul Gambia

title: Better places else where
text:
Pretty poor attraction. As said before, the animals caged at the back of the reserve are poorly maintained and look unhappy.
Go else where!

placeInfo.name: Abuko Nature Reserve
placeInfo.address: 15 Miles South of Banjul Kombo North District, Banjul Gambia

title: Ei paljoa nähtävää
text: Odotukset olivat korkeammalla kuin mitä tämä paikka tarjosi. Nähtiin muutamia apinoita ja korppikotkia. Taukopaikalla kerättiin rahaa puistolle, mikä oli toki tapa muissakin nähtävyyksissä. Puiston toisella puolella oli häkissä hyeenoja, papukaija ja jokunen apina, jotka kävivät sääliksi.

placeInfo.name: Abuko Nature Reserve
placeInfo.address: 15 Miles South of Banjul Kombo North District, Banjul Gambia

title: A nice walk, but not much else . . .
text:
Situated on the side of the airport road to Serekunda and the beach resorts, the park is easily reached by taxi from most hotels, and is an ideal ‘on your own’ half day out when you have exhausted your tour operators organised trip portfolio.

The self-appointed title ‘Nature Reserve’ does however raise the expectations of the first time visitor, which are unlikely to be met, hence the string of negative reviews.
On arrival, first stop is the ticket hut, where you are relieved of a modest 35 Dalasi each . . . so far so good. You are then directed to an open hut where several ‘guides’ are waiting. We told them we had been before and were happy to go unaccompanied; the reply is ‘snakes sir; lots of snakes . . . if you don’t know where to look, very dangerous’.
The guides were all wearing combat trousers tucked into high laced army boots while I was wearing M&S linen shorts with a pair of Reeboks; I figured they may well have a point.
In an act of extortion that The Peaky Blinders would be proud of, we were instantly relieved of a further 300D, but they had not finished yet . . . ‘you will need binoculars’ they tell us, and whoosh, another 100 changes hands.
What follows is in essence a very nice walk following a well worn path through shady and peaceful woodland, a few birds along the way but nothing you won’t see around your hotel, an army of ants crossing the path, some epic spider’s webs, but not much else.
Next stop is the natural lake containing several hard to spot crocs; you are led up wooden steps to an observation platform which doubles up as a gift shop; another hard sell along the lines of ‘the park runs on donations and what the tourists spend’;  we were in need of a few trinkets for nieces back home, but sadly the variety of gifts was on par with the variety of wildlife, and we escaped wallet intact and empty handed.
Another meandering walk with more of the same; 20 years ago, the path was lined with monkeys, eager to be fed with the bananas that were sold at the entrance; no bananas this time, and no monkeys; there is now a snack stall at the enclosures, and the monkeys learned very quickly that simply hanging around here will keep them well fed with the minimum effort.
They have however become very spiteful and greedy, and will quickly snatch the newly purchased bag of monkey nuts from your hand. The photo opportunities are there, if not a little predictable and staged, and short of a few hyenas in a large pen not much else here to detain you.
Exit is via another walk along another path, and is a different place to your drop-off, but your taxi driver will know this and be waiting for you. A gift shop is at the exit, giving another couple of desperate women one last opportunity to mug you before you disappear forever. The guide then hints heavily that he is not paid and relies on tips; you say I have already paid 300, he says yes but I don’t get that, we part with one final 200 for the guide and find our taxi.
We asked our driver to stop off at Lamin Lodge on the way back for a lunch break; we then detoured back via the pharmacy for a few bits, then the mini market for a few more; all in all, a good half day away from resort, but a nice shady walk only; no more, no less.
Hugely overpriced for what it is; (we spent 670D plus cokes and monkey nuts); better opportunities locally to resort for both monkeys and crocs, and at a fraction of the price.
Don’t expect too much; don’t bother with binoculars, and ditch the guide if you can.

placeInfo.name: Abuko Nature Reserve
placeInfo.address: 15 Miles South of Banjul Kombo North District, Banjul Gambia

title: Don't bother coming from the beach resorts
text: I happened to be staying nearby waiting for a flight so spent the morning walking around the reserve. Don't expect to see any wildlife except birds and a couple of monkeys. The animal "orphanage" is really depressing and the guides let a tourist get in the enclosure with two hyenas which makes me think they have no idea how to deal with and treat animals. I only gave two stars because the forest itself is quite nice to walk around and I came with low expectations but I had the opportunity of taking a day trip from one of the beach resorts earlier in my holiday and I'm really glad I didn't

placeInfo.name: Abuko Nature Reserve
placeInfo.address: 15 Miles South of Banjul Kombo North District, Banjul Gambia

title: Absolutely awful
text:
I went there with a friend last week ( 2/12/17)
We went equipped with a book of birds, binoculars, 'ít aint half hot' outfits etc expecting to see wild birds in their natural habitats etc.
There were no birds at all.
 Only a few baboons and a couple of wolves like creatures  in cages and that, as they say, was that.
This is a classic case of a really good bloke who had a dream once that was realised and when it was created and nurtured, it must have been fabulous.
Now, it is a ghost town birdwatching place with no birds but just bumsters having taken over what was once probably something worth seeing.
Don't go.
There is nothing here to see.
The local chancers have taken what's left of a dream over and the place is a shell.
There is nothing to see. 
Really. 

Don't waste your money.
Don't do it.
This is a vacuous dump.

placeInfo.name: Abuko Nature Reserve
placeInfo.address: 15 Miles South of Banjul Kombo North District, Banjul Gambia

title: Dubious interest to a casual tourist
text:
I've visited this site several times in search of birds.  Whilst home to many species (some of them very rare) they are not easy to see in the forest, and I'm not convinced that this is a location that a casual tourist would enjoy.  If you do go, make sure you take your insect repellent!

The "animal orphanage" is a central element of most visits, but the conditions under which the animals and birds are kept are really depressing.

placeInfo.name: Abuko Nature Reserve
placeInfo.address: 15 Miles South of Banjul Kombo North District, Banjul Gambia

title: Vogelparadijs
text: Erg mooi bos, je kan goed zien hoe divers de natuur kan zijn/is. Veel vogels, vooral bij het krokodillenpoeltje kan je heel lekker kijken. De dieren in de kooitjes vond ik erg triest, ik heb ze bewust overgeslagen.

placeInfo.name: Abuko Nature Reserve
placeInfo.address: 15 Miles South of Banjul Kombo North District, Banjul Gambia

title: Déçus !
text:
Nous avions auparavant visité d'autres réserves en Gambie et celle ci nous a déçu.
Nous avions prit un supplément pour avoir un guide et un autre supplément pour louer des jumelles.
Résultats nous n'avons même pas utilisé les jumelles car nous n'avons pas vu d'oiseaux. 
Les seuls animaux que nous avons vu:
Un cobra au loin (juste un d'entre nous l'a vu).
Un crocodile et quelques singes dans les arbres. 

Au milieu de la visite nous avons vu des hyènes et des vautours enfermés dans un enclos...

Il était difficile de comprendre le guide. Pendant la visite il a passé son temps le nez sur son téléphone. 

Points positifs : le lieu est facile à trouver et cela vous fera une balade agréable sous les arbres.

placeInfo.name: Abuko Nature Reserve
placeInfo.address: 15 Miles South of Banjul Kombo North District, Banjul Gambia

title: Wonderful forest to walk through
text:
Abuko nature reserve isn’t like the big safari parks.

There isn’t any big wildlife here but there’s plenty other stuff to see and check out.

The walk itself takes about a good hour and it’s best to bring water and avoid the high noon. 
We saw some of the big lizards, monkeys and beautiful spiders. It is said there are some cobra an python snakes as well in the area but you’ll have to be lucky.

Halfway the walk there is this big tree with vultures. Loads of them sitting there. Best not stand underneath them too long...😁

The Hyena’s aren’t there anymore and neither the crocodile. They have been replaced.

As it is with nature parks...you can be really lucky, or really out of luck.

With an entrance fee of 40 dalasi each it’s worth a shot!

placeInfo.name: Abuko Nature Reserve
placeInfo.address: 15 Miles South of Banjul Kombo North District, Banjul Gambia

title: Don't waste your time without a knowledgable and private guide
text:
This is a good reserve if you are really interested in exploring the nature and go without any set expectations.  There is no point going there just to tick the box on the places you visited.  You need a proper, experienced and knowledgable guide with you to enjoy this park.  I do not recommend taking "any" guide at the park as most of them are useless.  Also do not go in large groups as you will scare the animals out and will only be able to see the ones in the cage.  You need to have a lot of patience and stamina to walk for at least 90 minutes.  The best time to visit is in the morning when the sun is not heavy on you.  We went during the rainy season so it was a different experience altogether.  However, the walking paths were a bit muddy and we had to be extra careful but we thoroughly enjoyed our outing.  We had an excellent guide with us who was very knowledgable and knew everything about the park.  He was our private guide, not costly at all.  If you are visiting this country then spend a little extra it will be worth the experience you get compared to others.  We saw many beautiful birds on our way as well lot of red monkeys.  They are very shy of humans so make sure you do not make any noise when you spot them.  It is a treasure to see them jumping from the tree branches or just sitting over there.  We spotted two chameleons and our guide said that you must very lucky to have them.  He got one of them before it ran away and put them on a stick and handed it over to us.  We could see it changing colors before we let it go free in the wild and had enough of pictures with it.  The experience with Hyena was great as well as this was the first time I saw them and so close.  They do look dangerous but we had a 
Ranger protecting us while we take our picture with them having behind us in the close proximity.  The Rangers will be quite supportive if you go with a known guide and that is the difference.  They too will share lot of knowledge with you.  Eventually, you need to be friendly and taking interest and then everything else will automatically fall in place.  Don't be like another tourist.

placeInfo.name: Abuko Nature Reserve
placeInfo.address: 15 Miles South of Banjul Kombo North District, Banjul Gambia

title: Leuk om te zien maar...
text: Leuk om te zien maar niet heel spectaculair het is leuk voor een halve dag toer en misschien xtra leuk voor vogel liefhebbers want die zijn er veel in verschillende soorten. Hier zie je bv hyena's. Gieren. Bavianen. Enz. Is ook niet erg groot op je gemak 45 minuten ben je rond. En hyena's aanraken kun je ook niet overal maar hier dus wel.

placeInfo.name: Abuko Nature Reserve
placeInfo.address: 15 Miles South of Banjul Kombo North District, Banjul Gambia

title: Abuko
text: The national reservation abuko is nice place to visit during your stay in gambia despite there is not so much to see , but you can go inside the cage with hyena for example so good place for brave people.

placeInfo.name: Abuko Nature Reserve
placeInfo.address: 15 Miles South of Banjul Kombo North District, Banjul Gambia

title: Birdwatching with Mustapha Barry
text:
One of the first trips i made was Abuko nature park. I was with Mustapha Barry,birdwatching guide, i was amazed by his knowledge about birds and nature,
We had a nice walk and he spotted the most butifull birds like the violet and green Turaco, red-billes Hornbill,swallow-tailed Bee-eater and many more.
Also differend kind of monkeys . It was a very nice experience especially to do it with Mustapha Barry and i can recommend him as being honest,reliable and driver with his own 4x4 car. You can contact him at Kotu Bridge or by telephone (+220) 7165867

placeInfo.name: Abuko Nature Reserve
placeInfo.address: 15 Miles South of Banjul Kombo North District, Banjul Gambia

title: Vogels spotten
text:
Abuko was het eerste stuk natuur dat, drie jaar na de onafhankelijkheid van Gambia in 1965, officieel werd aangemerkt als beschermd natuurreservaat. Het is één van de kleinste parken in heel West-Afrika. Maar de biodiversiteit is er hoog.

Over de uitgezette route binnen het nog geen 200 hectare omvattende park loop je van dun begroeide savanne binnen mum van tijd het dichte en groene tropisch regenwoud in.

Dertig meter hoge palmen en mahoniebomen omringen je in het holst van het park. Hun altijd groene bladerdek beneemt je deels het felle zonlicht.
Abuko is een plek voor vogelspotters bij uitstek. Neem dus vooral je verrekijker mee en geniet van de vele honderden vogels die je voorbij ziet fladderen.
Breng een bezoek aan de Makasutu Wildlife Trust, een onderzoekscentrum dat zich bezighoud met studies naar Gambia's biodiversiteit.

placeInfo.name: Abuko Nature Reserve
placeInfo.address: 15 Miles South of Banjul Kombo North District, Banjul Gambia

title: Boswandeling
text: Boswandeling met als afsluiting een bezoekje aan de 3 Bavianen en 5 hyena's. Niet speciaal maar het was lekker wandelen!

placeInfo.name: Abuko Nature Reserve
placeInfo.address: 15 Miles South of Banjul Kombo North District, Banjul Gambia

title: Nice forest but sad caged animals
text:
The forest itself is a nice and peaceful place where you can see some animals in their natural habitat. Even some rare elusive red monkeys may be seen. You can spend a relaxing hour or two walking the trails and listening the nature.

However, there are some caged animals, such as hyenas and baboons, where the trails start. They didn't seem to be doing very well and had very small space to move around in their cages.

placeInfo.name: Abuko Nature Reserve
placeInfo.address: 15 Miles South of Banjul Kombo North District, Banjul Gambia

title: Abuko
text:
When we first got there the guy behind the desk was so ignorant and wouldn't answer us and when he did he had such a bad attitude. 

Went around the park with a guide, very long walk, saw a few monkeys but he only really showed us trees and termite mounds, didn't see no birds, snakes or crocs.

He took us to the baboons and explained they are in cages as they are violent...
Went to see the large vulture that flew down from its perch to us, loads of other vultures flying about in the area. 
Went inside the hyenas den which was definitely an experience especially when they started walking towards us and wanting us to rub them like dogs and trying to play. I didn't know hyenas could be friendly!!

Then on leaving the park there is a massive hippos head on display, the guide said they killed the hippo as he was eating the locals rice fields, told him it's cruel and sick for keeping the head on display, he didn't agree....
 
The park has potential to be better and house more animals as it did a few years back but they need to make sure animals are taken care of and I don't think tourists will appreciate seeing a rotting hippo head!!

Apart from that, nice few hours out and a lot of walking.

placeInfo.name: Abuko Nature Reserve
placeInfo.address: 15 Miles South of Banjul Kombo North District, Banjul Gambia

title: Stunning bird life
text:
West African Reserves are not to be compared with the Wild Parks of  East Africa or
Botswana. The main attraction of Abuko are the rare Red Colobus Ape and the truly stunning birdlife, so the best thing to do is to stroll the Reserve accompanied by a good bird guide. There are two hides available for birders.

placeInfo.name: Abuko Nature Reserve
placeInfo.address: 15 Miles South of Banjul Kombo North District, Banjul Gambia

title: Two hides available and assisted our photography out of the sun.
text: If you are bird watching or photographing then this is a must visit sight. We saw a good number of species including green and Violet Turacos along with giant Kingfishers.

placeInfo.name: Abuko Nature Reserve
placeInfo.address: 15 Miles South of Banjul Kombo North District, Banjul Gambia

title: Not many animals!
text: We had a nice walk round the park, but did not see any animals, and not many birds. Maksutu Cultural Forest or the monkey park near Senegambia were more fun.

placeInfo.name: Abuko Nature Reserve
placeInfo.address: 15 Miles South of Banjul Kombo North District, Banjul Gambia

title: Caged animals in awful conditions
text:
The 'protected' forest itself is very disappointing and most of the animals have left, bar a few monkeys. We walked through the forest with a guide but there really was nothing to point out. At the end you come to a 'rescue' centre. There are caged vultures, monkeys, tortoise, pelicans (all in one cage) and loads of uncastrated hyenas in others. 
Not a nice experience at all and sadly the 'staff' couldn't understand why we thought it was cruel and that this wasn't something that tourists wanted to see.
Very sad! Please don't visit!

placeInfo.name: Abuko Nature Reserve
placeInfo.address: 15 Miles South of Banjul Kombo North District, Banjul Gambia

title: Interesting place
text: This place is beautiful if your after a sedate but long nature walk with lots of birds and monkeys. The animal orphanage needs some tlc and some education on environment and animal rehabilitation but they are making the best of a bad job! It is worth a visit especially if you see the endangered west red colobus monkeys.

placeInfo.name: Abuko Nature Reserve
placeInfo.address: 15 Miles South of Banjul Kombo North District, Banjul Gambia

title: Amazing monkeys
text: Great place to visit although quite a long walk. The monkeys are wonderful to see but the other animals in the cages don't seem quite as happy although still well looked after.

placeInfo.name: Abuko Nature Reserve
placeInfo.address: 15 Miles South of Banjul Kombo North District, Banjul Gambia

title: An Amazing Area of African Forest Close to Banjul
text: This nature preserve/research station/wild animal rehabilitation site is a must visit for anyone interested in the natural history of Gambia.  The trails are safe and easy to follow, but be careful not to stop on/near a stream of ants on the move.  Local experts are available to guide birders and further information is available at the observation deck of the Darwin Research Station.

placeInfo.name: Abuko Nature Reserve
placeInfo.address: 15 Miles South of Banjul Kombo North District, Banjul Gambia

title: Day trip
text: Beautiful place to visit for young and young at heart, monkeys were amazing, a little greedy but very friendly 😁

placeInfo.name: Abuko Nature Reserve
placeInfo.address: 15 Miles South of Banjul Kombo North District, Banjul Gambia

title: TODO MUY SUCIO
text: Habían muchos monos pero el descuido de este parque es total.Todo lleno de basura y el personal no tiene interés alguno por los visitantes.

placeInfo.name: Abuko Nature Reserve
placeInfo.address: 15 Miles South of Banjul Kombo North District, Banjul Gambia

title: A simple forest reserve
text: You can see only voltures and Monkeys and a few hyaenas. It may be a good idea to take a walk with a guide. It is a different place in the Gambia.

placeInfo.name: Abuko Nature Reserve
placeInfo.address: 15 Miles South of Banjul Kombo North District, Banjul Gambia

title: Klein maar fijn.
text:
De natuur is prachtig en je kan er een heerlijke wandeling maken en veel vogels spotten. Er is ook een soort mini zoo met een paar leuke dieren zoals hyenas. Vele mensen hebben hier al gereageerd hoe verschrikkelijk ze het vinden dat de dieren in kooien zitten maar het is niet veel anders dan de zoo in ons thuisland. 
Ook wist de gids ons te vertellen dat veel dieren hier zitten om een nieuwe groep te vormen van mannetjes en vrouwtjes om zo hopelijk weer in het wild te kunnen leven.

placeInfo.name: Abuko Nature Reserve
placeInfo.address: 15 Miles South of Banjul Kombo North District, Banjul Gambia

title: A nice place to walk but I don't want to see anyone in cages
text:
Most of the Abuko park is nice and the monkeys are free, but there's also a part where they keep some monkeys and even an eagle in cages! The cages are too small and they do not seem to have a nice and happy life. I don't think that such intelligent creatures should be held in a prison and it made me sad to see that.

But if you skip the zoo part you might enjoy it, because it's a really nice place for a walk. They don't want to let you go inside without a local guide, but don't mind them, you won't get lost! If you get a guide, you need to pay for the entrance fee and also some tip to the guide - not worth it. You'll see the monkeys and lots of birds anyway :)

placeInfo.name: Abuko Nature Reserve
placeInfo.address: 15 Miles South of Banjul Kombo North District, Banjul Gambia

title: Interesting venue
text: We have visited a couple of times on our way to and from other attractions.  Interesting  walk and park even for those who are not serious bird watchers.  Also a small zoo.

placeInfo.name: Abuko Nature Reserve
placeInfo.address: 15 Miles South of Banjul Kombo North District, Banjul Gambia

title: Nothing outstanding but a nice nature walk
text:
We visited this park along with Lamin Lodge on a tour from Kololi. 

They insisted we paid for a tour guide to take us through the park, the guide was very uninformative, not really talking to us or telling us about the park but simply trying to get around as quickly as possible the forcibly asking for a large tip. It would have been much nicer to simply take our time and wonder through the reserve.

It was generally a pretty reserve and we did see some green vervet monkeys who were quite happy to have their photo taken but if this is what you are looking for then Bijilo park is a much better nature park with more monkeys and just as nice/nicer scenery.

There were Baboons and Hyenas in cages in one section but I tend not to like seeing animals unnecessarily in cages so did not find this an enjoyable part of the park. They had also had a hippo there which had died recently and they kept its head on display (not pleasant to look at!)   

We had a nice day but I didn't think this park and any advantages over Bijilo

placeInfo.name: Abuko Nature Reserve
placeInfo.address: 15 Miles South of Banjul Kombo North District, Banjul Gambia

title: Vogelspotten maar weinig wilde apen
text: Vogelspotten is leuk, maar niet heel veel te zien! Veel gieren. Leuke wandeling door de natuur. Enkele apen in het wild gezien. Hyena's en apen opgesloten...

placeInfo.name: Abuko Nature Reserve
placeInfo.address: 15 Miles South of Banjul Kombo North District, Banjul Gambia

title: Triest om deze dieren achter lelijk gaas te zien.
text:
Met een privé gids dit park aan het einde van de dag bezocht.
We mochten met de auto naar het terrein waar de hyena's waren. We zagen de hyena's in een grote ren achter een dubbele laag kippengaas. In een andere ren zaten een paar apen ,een jong hert, een schildpad en een gier. Diverse apen konden zich wel vrij bewegen. We waren niet gecharmeerd van deze plek. Nu ik de geplaatste foto 's bekijk denk ik dat onze gids ons veel niet heeft laten zien.

placeInfo.name: Abuko Nature Reserve
placeInfo.address: 15 Miles South of Banjul Kombo North District, Banjul Gambia

title: Book A Guide BEFORE You Go
text:
As much as I wanted to visit Abuko I was almost put off by some of the things said in the negative reviews but we were booking some bird watching trips with a bird guide and he assured us it was an important place to visit. He was not wrong! 
Our very informative guide, Musa Manneh (+220) 7834098, showed us a total of 51 different species of wonderful colourful and spectacular birds that day along with an abundance of information about the various plant, insect and animal species we were seeing along our walk. Although he predominantly a bird guide he is very knowledgeable about the natural history of Gambia and will give insights into the local culture too. 
It is very evident to me that the way to get the best out of this place is to arrange with someone who understands it to take you there. Avoid booking a trip with a mini bus full of people, you will disturb any wildlife as the mass of people tramp through the well trod paths of the reserve. Individual guiding is not as expensive as you might imagine in The Gambia and it pays massive dividends in how much it improves your experience of these places. You only have limited time during your holiday so why waste it by handing a poultry sum to a bumster who will walk with you but not give you any insight or understanding to the things you are seeing and not help you to see the things that prefer not to be seen! 
During our time there so many people walked right past us as we were standing watching some magnificent bird, once or twice people would stop to look in the direction I was pointing my camera lens and we would point out what we were seeing. 
A guide you have employed to take you there will ensure you avoid unwelcome advances from the bumsters and ensure you are proceeding at a pace that suits your stamina and ability, at least that is what we experienced with Musa. 
We set off early so we could avoid being there at the hottest time of the day. Musa also took us to explore an area of paddy fields opposite the reserve before we went in and that area was simply amazing. If anyone wished to book him before they leave home then they can do so via email musaamanneh56@yahoo.com and you can find his website by typing Musa Manneh Bird Watching Tours into your search engine. The man is a gentleman who will provide a car with a very safe driver and take great care of you, he speaks perfect English too.

placeInfo.name: Abuko Nature Reserve
placeInfo.address: 15 Miles South of Banjul Kombo North District, Banjul Gambia

title: Great Photo opportunities
text: We visited Abuko as part of trip with Arch tours and really enjoyed it, great photo opportunities for bird watching and general wildlife.  We saw loads of different birds including a giant kingfisher. At the end of the trail is a small zoo area which has baboons and Hyenas, however this is not best part of reserve.

placeInfo.name: Abuko Nature Reserve
placeInfo.address: 15 Miles South of Banjul Kombo North District, Banjul Gambia

title: Niet de moeite
text: Zat mee in een tourpakket maar geen aanrader ... Niks te zien ... Enkel op het eind paar apen in kooi .... Jammer niet aan te raden

placeInfo.name: Abuko Nature Reserve
placeInfo.address: 15 Miles South of Banjul Kombo North District, Banjul Gambia

title: a long walk to a small zoo
text: Abuko costs very little to get in - less than £1. The guide didn't really talk to us so we gained little from having him. Essentially you walk a long way to see animals in cages - not what we expected. Although the animal keepers took us inside the hyena pen which was pretty amazing. Then the long walk back and pushy market sellers on the way out - you have to be firm if you don't want to buy! Much preferred bijilo park.

placeInfo.name: Abuko Nature Reserve
placeInfo.address: 15 Miles South of Banjul Kombo North District, Banjul Gambia

title: Leuker dan de dierentuin
text: Een mooie trip gemaakt naar Abuko. Gebruik gemaakt van 'tanka tanka', dat wil zeggen steeds overstappen op lokale taxi's die heen en weer tijden tussen vaste punten. Spotgoedkoop. Een lokale gids is wel een aanrader. Even onderhandelen over de prijs is zinvol. Neem er de tijd voor, want het is ook een heerlijk wandelgebied. Stel je niet te veel voor van de diersoorten. In ieder geval heb je die gids nodig om deze dieren te zien. Voor wat betreft mogelijk gevaarlijke dieren zoals de hongerige krokodillen, zou ik zeggen: die heb je nodig om ze tijdig te zien!

placeInfo.name: Abuko Nature Reserve
placeInfo.address: 15 Miles South of Banjul Kombo North District, Banjul Gambia

title: Scam
text:
Just a word of warning,the so called guides at Abouko have nothing whatsover to do with Abouko Park,they are just chancers or 'Bumsters' if anyone cares to look at earlier previous posts it will be explained in more detail there,since the funding for the park was stopped a few years ago all the official guides are well gone. If your putting money in a box at the lodge next to the so called croc pool that goes straight into the bumsters pocket.
Regarding 'Eagle Heights' with the Lion Cubs,Cheetahs etc ( all poisoned) it was a front for a bird of prey import scam to the UK,which is well documented on Facebook.

placeInfo.name: Abuko Nature Reserve
placeInfo.address: 15 Miles South of Banjul Kombo North District, Banjul Gambia

title: Poor quality zoo with some wild monkeys.
text:
Situated just outside town this reserve is said to host “displaced” animals in an attempt to help preserve Gambias wildlife.  There are plenty of sightings of Vervet Monkeys which are well habituated to humans (they can be very amusing)  and some Red Colobus Monkeys are also present.  

But essentially it’s really just a small open air zoo.  A troop of Baboons is kept in a fairly spacious enclosure,  with a couple of cages Hyena nearby to the drinks stall.
People tell of ongoing improvement work,  but there was no sight of actual improvement on the ground since 2012,  and considerable degradation since that visit.

Worth a visit  -  I don’t think so.

placeInfo.name: Abuko Nature Reserve
placeInfo.address: 15 Miles South of Banjul Kombo North District, Banjul Gambia

title: Nice walk
text: Visited here with my gambian boyfriend, my son and another couple. I thought it was a really nice walk and plenty of animals to see. I particularly liked the fact that the majority of them were free to roam around.

placeInfo.name: Abuko Nature Reserve
placeInfo.address: 15 Miles South of Banjul Kombo North District, Banjul Gambia

title: Excellent place to  see birds, crododiles and small mammals
text: If you like nature, this is a must see in Gambia. In particular the view point on the little lake was marvellous with its many birds and crocodiles. We saw several monkeys. There are fierce looking hyenas in a separate fenced area.

placeInfo.name: Abuko Nature Reserve
placeInfo.address: 15 Miles South of Banjul Kombo North District, Banjul Gambia

title: A lot has changed in a year
text: The park was a good day out last year with hyena, cheetahs, a lion cub and monkeys, however in the past year both cheetahs and the lion cub have died raising my concerns. The monkeys and hyenas are still nice to see though

placeInfo.name: Abuko Nature Reserve
placeInfo.address: 15 Miles South of Banjul Kombo North District, Banjul Gambia

title: A bit diasapointing
text: We went here by taxi and a guide was waiting for us to show us around. The guide seemed to be in a rush and didn't take time to tell u something about the parc. We saw some monkeys but you can see them in many places around. There are some hyena's and other types of monkeys but they are caged and seemed to be very bored. It is easy to find your way around the parc, a guide is really not needed, so I would save the money next time.

En una mañana puedes ver entre varias decenas de especies de aves africanas. Lo ideal es estar en la puerta a primera hora y entrar según abren la puerta... Es una pena ver las hienas en la jaula en malas condiciones... Por lo demás muy recomendable.

placeInfo.name: Abuko Nature Reserve

title: Zonde van de tijd
text:
Aangezien Abuko was opgenomen in een excursie, gingen we hier heen met onze gids. Maar het was zonde van de tijd. Er zit geen wild, of je moet de opgesloten bavianen, de gier ende hyena's als wild zien. Deze dieren zitten in veel te kleine kooien opgesloten. Het is dieronvriendelijk. In de vijver zou ook nog een verdwaalde krokodil moeten zitten, maar die hebben we niet gezien.
Als je Abuko niet zou bezoeken, dan mis je niets.

placeInfo.name: Abuko Nature Reserve

title: Enkele aapjes en de rest achter tralies
text:
Er zijn wat aapjes, maar die zie je elders ook. De antilopes zijn al opgegeten door de omliggende dorpen (aldus onze gids), de krokodillen zijn altijd onderwater (jaja) en de bavianen en heyena's zitten opgesloten in veel te kleine ruimtes of kooien, een vreselijke vertoning. Je loopt een beste wandeling (niet geschikt voor kleine kinderen of ouderen) en ziet bijna niets. 
Samengevat, wegblijven!!

placeInfo.name: Abuko Nature Reserve
placeInfo.address: 15 Miles South of Banjul Kombo North District, Banjul Gambia

title: Perhaps Not A Fair Review
text: A taxi driver took me here recently only to be told when we arrived that the place was closed. He was surprised to hear this. However, I spoke a few days later with a different, experienced taxi driver that I have done a lot of business with, and he explained to me that many of the animals that had been there had died, which is why they had to close their doors. I am not sure what happened and I am not sure when they will be opening again but I thought I would post the information I was give here for other people who might be planning to visit Abuko.

placeInfo.name: Abuko Nature Reserve

title: Beautiful
text:
Lovely walks through forest,  chance to see Crocs in the Lake, and in the centre they had free roaming monkeys who came and happily took peanuts from your hands, and anything in your pockets was lovely. My best experience was befriending a young baboon there, he was very friendly and affectionate and was a delight seeing him playing with the other Monkeys. They had hyenas there, vultures and a little place to get a bite to eat. Easily spend a couple of hours there. 
You can take a guide or go in on your own,  easy to find your way around doing it alone. 
Truly loved it!

placeInfo.name: Abuko Nature Reserve
placeInfo.address: 15 Miles South of Banjul Kombo North District, Banjul Gambia

title: Money scam
text:
I had an experience very similar to that of zippideedoodle below.

My group and I (consisting of Gambians and Europeans interested in conservation and wildlife) had wanted to explore the park freely for the local wild nature.  We were pressured into hiring a guide who was not overall very informative but did point out some different species, 

The guided then took us out a side gate to Eagle Heights, without informing us this is what was happening. He wanted us to pay another guided to show us some of the animals they have there  - an experience we didn't even want. We did not pay and got walked back along the road to the entrance of the nature reserve. 

It could have been a very different experience.

placeInfo.name: Abuko Nature Reserve
placeInfo.address: 15 Miles South of Banjul Kombo North District, Banjul Gambia

title: Warning! Reserve Now Occupied by Unmonitored Scammer Bumsters!
text:
The Abuko Nature Reserve is a large forest protected by the Government of The Gambia. It was once developed and maintained by the University of Warwick in the UK as a Darwin Field Station for biodiversity study, a project that ended in 2005. Since then, the developed portions of the Reserve have been abandoned and taken over by "bumsters" who know nothing about nature or biodiversity, but have figured out a number of scams to take your money. 

For example, the true entry fee for the park is 15 Dalasis as shown on the official receipt you are given...upon payment of 400 Dalasis!. In my case, I did not notice the receipt until I had paid the 400 Dalasis...too late sucker! Mysteriously, I was given a sticker to enter a privately owned exotic animal zoo on the highway outside of the park as a consolation. These "proprietors" apparently figured out an arrangement with the owners of the zoo to sell entry to that separate enterprise, off-site, under the guise that it was a mandatory fee to enter the Reserve. I was then asked for another 100 Dalasis to rent a pair of binoculars with no strap. I later found that the 10 X 50 glasses had been dropped and damaged so that the mirror prisms inside had been knocked out of alignment rendering them useless. Inasmuch as they were extremely heavy and without a strap, I simply pitched them into my sack and carried on with my own self-guided walk through the pathways of the Reserve. 

I respectfully declined the extremely high pressure mandatory but voluntary but mandatory requirement to hire a guide for another 300 Dalasis because I did not want to be accompanied by an unofficial "guide" who knew nothing about the faunna, flora and wildlife except what one could see anyway with the naked eye. The last thing I wanted was someone talking to me incessantly for the duration of my experience which did turn out to be a very beautiful 2-hour stroll through a luxurant forest full of wildlife. 

About halfway into the Park, I came across the remains of the Darwin Biodiversity Field Station which is adorned with old rotting posters and two bumsters dressed in disco garb and sunglasses who, not surprisingly, were requesting more "donations." They presented a "guestbook" that was undated, but appeared to be signed by people who were donating up to 500 Dalasis for a project that unbeknownst to them was terminated in 2005. The donation box was not only unlocked, but it had disappeared with the slot simply allowing the money to fall on the floor. When I asked who would get the money, the "boys," probably in their late 20s,  stated that the money would go to "the man." The station had some displays of bones that the boys had collected in the forest, lying on a table, and the remnants of old biodiversity exhibits. This field station offered no information about what was going on in the park. 

Notably, no one in the park, at the entrance or at this field station, could sell me a simple map of the park. For all the come-ons for money, one would have thought the easiest sell would have been a map of the park itself so that patrons like myself could find their way around the winding pathways, as obvious as they are. But then, enabled with a map, who would need a guide? This was a very simple thing to prepare and distribute for which I would have paid gladly. The absence of maps ws designed to compel the purchase of a guide. Who wants foreign visitors to have a pleasant walk through the park on their own? Certainly the proprietors do not. 

Nevertheless, continuing on from the field station, I had an extremely pleasant experience noting crocodiles, many more exotic birds than I had anticipated, and plenty of monkeys. It truly is a beautiful experience if you would like to take a walk for a couple of hours on your own. At all costs, however, I would avoid the sucker plays of everyone who is offering you something for money, especially their delightful company and incessant banter while you are trying to listen to the nature and take it all in. 

Near end of the pathway on the interior of the park there is what appears to be a legitimate zoo which contains hyenas, baboons and wild monkeys. These animals are kept in these cages on the explanation that they were once domesticated and the proprietors are attempting to allow them to re-adapt to their natural environment. They would be released in six months. I cannot imagine who would have domesticated the hyenas that I saw in those cages. They were huge! Domesticated baboons? Finally, the exit trail leads you onto, of all place,  the main highway far from your starting point. There you will find the UK owned zoo that contains some exotic animals outside of their natural habitat such as lions and cheetahs. Although I had unwittingly been forced to pay for entry into the Reserve, I passed on the idea, walked down the driveway onto the main highway, and then walked about three quarters of a kilometer down the highway to reunite with my vehicle at the entry of the park. It seemed an odd configuration to enter at one end, and then be dumped onto a main highway only to walk along noisy and fierce traffic to get back to your starting point. 

In the end, I did enjoy the walk and the exposure to nature that I found there. I'm afraid, however, that the fact that it has been spoiled by fraudulent tricks and and parasitic squatters who have taken over a once well-maintained biodiversity project assured me that I would not return to this place. Left alone, it is a beautiful place. Unfortunately, it is been spoiled by the unnatural. There are many other better maintained or unmaintained nature reserves in The Gambia that are well worth my time and money. Be forewarned!

text: Hired our own guide for a walk around this very manageable wildlife park. Saw some memorable sights including crocodiles, pygmy bee eaters, fire-finches and an African darter. There is a rather sad zoo towards the rear of the park where there are one or two sorry looking hyenas and baboons but I understand that the plan is to improve this facility in conjunction with the near-by Eagle Heights Park which is also worth a visit.

title: wildlife Gem
text: This is a huge nature park.  It has fascinating flora and fauna. If you are a nature lover with an interest in birds, it's a must! We were lucky enough to see two species of Deer and crocodiles - spotted by our eagle eyed bird guide, Ansu Dunor.  I cannot recommend him highly enough.  He was very patient with us and wished to ensure we saw as much as possible. Beware of fake guides - to ensure a good guide, we recommend you ask for Ansu at the Bird Watchers Association located next to the Bridge in Kotu.

title: Very Highly Recommended
text: Excellent and very knowledgeable guide Ismaela showed us many animals and kept us save as he walked with us around the park.  He took us on a long tour and allowed us to borrow his binoculars to view the crocodiles and kingfishers around the water.  We also saw vultures, ospreys, termite mounds, bushbuck antelopes and inside the Eagle Heights Centre (which is within the Abuko Nature Reserve) we saw baby vultures, tortoises, birds of prey, a lion cub called Babar and even a cheetah couple!  Very educational and the conservation work they are doing here is excellent.  The animals are very well looked after and if any are in cages this is only ever for breeding or rehabilitation purposes.

title: Waste of time
text:
Arrived here early afternoon. As we didn't have much time, our driver wanted to drive us to the centre to see the hyenas & feed the monkeys. We have been a few times in the past, many years ago & had a good time, although I was never too keen on the condition the animals were kept in. We were taking friends out for a day & thought it would be nice to visit. 

On arrival our driver enquired about the price & said we just wanted to drive straight into the centre. He was told its 400 d each!!!! And we had to take a guide for the walk through the forest. I understand this is the guides only mean of income but we didn't want to do the walk, we've never had this problem before. We explained we only wanted to see the centre but was told we had to do all if it so we got back in the car. The man came over & said ok what will you pay for what you want to do. I said it's too late, as he was being greedy we would just go to lamin lodge for a drink. Bad luck, you lost out. 

Some other friends of ours did visit, on my recommendation (from past experiences) they said it was extremely overpriced, the animals were in appalling conditions & overall it was rubbish. Sorry guys, had I known how badly it had gone down hill & how expensive it was I would have told them not to bother. 

Stick to the crocodile pond at 50d each.

There was a very wounded hyena which was a little concerning, apparently he had fought with the others. All other animals seemed happy & healthy. Eagle heights is very new & therefore they don't have many animals to see but the staff are very knowledgeable.

title: A vast improvement at Abouko.
text:
New look Abouko. 
03 November 2014, 15:29
Lovely to see Abouko Park has been taken over by some responsible people,now renamed Eagle Heights,it puts on flying displays each morning,various new animals are presant including Leopards and baby lions and various raptors,its being well run and the animals are being well cared for,theres a new refreshments area and a nice shady lodge where you can now view the various activities,most important the various indigenous animal species will,overtime,be introduced back into the park,details are on FB.

03 November 2014, 15:34
Eagle Heights Gambia is NOW OPEN! 

Eagle Heights Gambia is based at the beautiful Abuko Nature Reserve in The Gambia, West Africa. Set among almost 500 acres you will be entranced by the flora and fauna around you. 

Currently at the Centre are our 2 Cheetah with which we are hoping to begin a successful breeding project. A selection of Birds of Prey including a Crowned Eagle, Lanner Falcon, Tawny Eagle and Bateleur Eagle! 

The current orphanage inside Abuko will be collaborating with us enabling us to move the Hyena from their current enclosure to a new and improved version. This also applies to the Baboons and any other animals that arrive at the orphanage from now on. 

Daily Talks will take place along with a flying demonstration. You will also be invited to take a pit stop at our Bar for an all important refreshment!

Following the opening of the centre we will then begin our second project, Reintroduction! We will be reintroducing many once indigenous species back into the Abuko Buffer Zone. These are species that once lived there naturally but were unfortunately wiped out by humans etc.

placeInfo.name: Abuko Nature Reserve
placeInfo.address: 15 Miles South of Banjul Kombo North District, Banjul Gambia

title: Superb!
text: Set In a dry rainforest there is much to see here, many birds of which there are too many to name an in terms of mammals if you arrive early and go to the hide that looks over the small lake you have a high chance of seeing vervet monkey, red colobus monkey, bushbuck, sun squirrel and if lucky sitatunga! There are also a pair of resident nile crocodiles that inhabit the lake.. You can see many of the kingfisher species here aswell as palm nut vulture, violet turaco, hammerkop and a few hornbill species! Small fee to get in but if you have a good guide the cost of your guide normally means they pay for you! At the end of the trail at Abuko there is a woodland bar where you can get close to the vervet monkeys but don't get too close as a scratch or bite could lead to worse! By the bar is an animal orphanage of injured wild animals in recovery including baboons, Patas monkey and spotted hyena
