text:
gran decepción, un par de monos, la mitad de ellos cerrados en jaulas, un mono cerrado en una jaula muy pequeña, te daba una pena, hienas tampoco no estaban en buenas condiciones, 
parque no esta preparado para los turistas, un bar estaba cerrado, solo uno abierto donde podrias comprar una Coca-Cola, nada mas, monos libres que aparecen allí y que puedes dar cacahutetes están también en otros sitios. bueno, no recomiendo, para gente que les gusta los animales, porque sales de allí triste. no puedo decir que mueren de hambre, pero condiciones son malos.

placeInfo.name: Abuko Nature Reserve
placeInfo.address: 15 Miles South of Banjul Kombo North District, Banjul Gambia

title: mooi maar vrij klein natuurpark
text: Het Abuko Nature reserve is een mooi natuurpark, maar verwacht hier niet een weeld eaan dieren zoals in de parken in Oost- en Zuid-Afrika. Wel veel vogels en apen, maar geen grote zoogdieren.

placeInfo.name: Abuko Nature Reserve
placeInfo.address: 15 Miles South of Banjul Kombo North District, Banjul Gambia

title: Видели крокодила
text: Мне парк очень понравился. На кассе пытаються втюрить экскурсовода, от услуг которых мы вежливо отказались, так как хотели погулять вдвоем. Билет стоит в районе 40 далласи. Мы с собой зяли нашего таксиста, чтобы он не скучал в машине, Для местных вход еще дешевле, около 15 далласи. В парке мы видели крокодила, много разных обезьян, интересные деревье. Я рекомендую, идти в парк с самого утра, так как можно встретить большее количество животных, которые после обеда прячутся. Цены на напитки в парке умеренные, можно купить арахис и бананы, чтобы покормить обезьян, но лучше взять это с собой.

placeInfo.name: Abuko Nature Reserve
placeInfo.address: 15 Miles South of Banjul Kombo North District, Banjul Gambia

title: Mucho mejor que Bijilo
text: El único sitio dónde contratamos un guía, la visita merece la pena, vimos cocodrilos, antílopes, muchos monos, ardillas, buitres y demás aves. Además tienen hienas, eso si, enjauladas, según nos contaron se trata de un proyecto de rehabilitación de estos animales, la verdad es que fue impresionante verlas en acción, llegamos justo cuando las alimentaban y estaban como locas riéndose y dando vueltas.

placeInfo.name: Abuko Nature Reserve
placeInfo.address: 15 Miles South of Banjul Kombo North District, Banjul Gambia

title: Great park, I enjoyed the trip
text: Lot of serious birders wandering around with massive cameras, the best place to see all sorts of birds, there is a small lake that attracts all sorts of birds and a few hides scattered around. They have Hyenas who are to fat to even chase the vultures away from pinching their food, never seen such fat animals. Also caged  baboons. The keeper told me most of these animals have been rescued from bad homes. I was concerned about a very skinny Baboon but I was told he was taken from a soldier who was not looking after him. They certainly do their best to look after the animals. Refreshments in the centre of the park with some seats in the shade, that was nice. I enjoyed the day, would recommend a visit

placeInfo.name: Abuko Nature Reserve
placeInfo.address: 15 Miles South of Banjul Kombo North District, Banjul Gambia

title: I expected more
text:
For such a big space i was expecting to see more animals. Our guide was great and very informative but the lack of animals was disappointing and i'm sure we walked a couple of hours. Apart from the two types of monkey that were roaming about (one type was the same as the ones that come to the hotel) the others were caged, the hyenas were just lying about because of the heat, the crocodiles were nowhere to be seen, and i saw one exotic looking bird (apart from the caged parrot)!
They said they were getting more animals in soon but it wasn't a very exciting walk unfortunately, but to be fair its not their fault that the animals were hiding, not around and tired.

placeInfo.name: Abuko Nature Reserve
placeInfo.address: 15 Miles South of Banjul Kombo North District, Banjul Gambia

title: Abouko......Disgraceful
text: This must be one of the most neglected parks I've ever seen,its got worse over the past 3 years . The caged animals are in a pityfull state. The baboon troop has dwindled from 40 animals to a handful,there kept in a bare cage,in another sparse cage was a vulture with a live monkey for company it was obviously the birds food! In the same cage last year was a giant tortoise and a pelcan,no sign of those and seeing the conditions they living in I fear the worse . The Hyenas were in a awful state ,one was surounded by vultures and it was obvious he was sick. Stay away if you are an animal lover or you will leave this hell hole  in tears.

placeInfo.name: Abuko Nature Reserve
placeInfo.address: 15 Miles South of Banjul Kombo North District, Banjul Gambia

title: Birders paradise;think again
text: This park like all the other parks we visited has been seriously neglected despite staff who sit about all day doing nothing. It is in need of signs; the lavatories need cleaning up and  like all parks geared for birdwatching it needs the provision of water so that birds can be observed.

placeInfo.name: Abuko Nature Reserve
placeInfo.address: 15 Miles South of Banjul Kombo North District, Banjul Gambia

title: Not much to see. Guides useless
text:
Went to Abuko Nature Reserve with good intentions, and was met by a guide that wanted 400 D for a tour (ended up with 300 D) and gave the impression it was manditory with a guide (it is not). He talked a little about the history of the park and the trees. Walked around paths with trees, bushes, a few birds, monkees and butterflies. Ended up at the orphanage with monkees and hyenas in cages.
Dissapointing experience.
If you go don´t take a guide.

placeInfo.name: Abuko Nature Reserve
placeInfo.address: 15 Miles South of Banjul Kombo North District, Banjul Gambia

title: Maybe need to go early in the morning?
text: There are mixed reviews for this park. We went late morning and were disappointed: little to see, some caged hyenas, self appointed guide, aggressive monkeys (not like Bijolo). Maybe the higher ratings are for early morning when there is more bird life? We saw four birds only. It takes two hours to walk around the one forest path.

placeInfo.name: Abuko Nature Reserve
placeInfo.address: 15 Miles South of Banjul Kombo North District, Banjul Gambia

title: Nothing to see
text:
Well, we really did not see anything else than the caged animals (poor hyenas, one was in a really small cage, baboons and turtles).

In the beginning the quide (who invited himself with us) told that we probably aint gonna see any animals.. cause they are sleeping or eating or what ever. And we really did not see anything, not even birds. We walked an hour in the "jungle". There was a "crocodile pool" where was supposed to be 50 or something crocodiles, didnt see any, and nobody else has seen.

Welt kind of like cheated, had to pay for the quide too. Felt bad cause of the caged animals. Aint gonna visit Abuko never again.

placeInfo.name: Abuko Nature Reserve
placeInfo.address: 15 Miles South of Banjul Kombo North District, Banjul Gambia

title: Nothing to see, apart from some caged Hyenas and Baboons - hassle from sellers
text: Went here on a trip out, expecting to see hundreds of varieties of birds. Saw less than 10. Paid the entrance fee, was then followed by a manager who asked for a donation for food - anything from 200 to 400D, I do not know what they spend the money on as there seems to be nothing here that they need to feed, apart from a few rescue animals (and only a few!). After a walk around, there is a visitors centre - where on entering you feel instantly pressured into buying a t-shirt or other souvenirs. About half way around there is a shop, and some people selling wood carvings. You cannot sit and have a drink here without being hassled into buying a wood carving. If you buy from one seller you then get hassled by the other seller to buy from them too as they need to money to buy food!. On exiting there are a number of wood carving stalls that you have to pass. The sellers come at you from all over - one dragged me to his stall by my arm and told me that he had not had any breakfast and asked if I would buy a simple darning for 'only 300D' so he could buy breakfast. DO NOT BUY FROM ONE OF THESE PRESSURE SELLERS OR THEY WILL ALL COME AFTER YOU FOR A SALE. On leaving the reserve, there are another two locals who will try and sell you chilled drinks for an upmarket price of D75 (they were only D20 in my hotel). Was a terrible day out, it would be a bit better if they cleared all the wood carving sellers away - or only let one or two sell - not around 10 that you have to pass on your way out, all selling the same things.

placeInfo.name: Abuko Nature Reserve
placeInfo.address: 15 Miles South of Banjul Kombo North District, Banjul Gambia

title: Do Not Go
text: Went here on a recent trip to gambia. Don't bother, not much to see but trees and the animals are kept in horrendous conditions, so who knows where the donations go.

placeInfo.name: Abuko Nature Reserve
placeInfo.address: 15 Miles South of Banjul Kombo North District, Banjul Gambia

title: Abuko
text: Mooie wandeling door het bos, met een vijver waar krokodillen zitten en een aapjes opvang! Er zaten ook twee hyena's.

placeInfo.name: Abuko Nature Reserve
placeInfo.address: 15 Miles South of Banjul Kombo North District, Banjul Gambia

title: Amper 'wilde' dieren gespot
text: Wij vonden dit park eigenlijk wat tegenvallen. De enige 'vrije' dieren die wij hebben gezien, waren dezelfde aapjes die je in Monkey Park (Bilijo Park) kan zien, dus als je moet kiezen, ga dan voor Monkey Park (er zitten er 10x meer)! De andere dieren (Bavianen, hyena's, een zelfdzame gier, schildpadden) zaten in veel te kleine kooien, en daarvoor kan je bij ons ook in de Zoo terecht. Ingang: 30 dalasi (=0,60EUR). Bijkomend minpunt: aan de ingang liep een man die vroeg voor donaties voor het park, maar zelfs onze lokale gids heeft ons dit afgeraden omdat je niet weet waar je geld terecht komt...

When we went, Wally did not have his own vehicle, but he adjusted his rate and we all took a taxi.

title: Después de visitar el zoo...refréscate con Jungle Man
text:
El African zoo es una más de las experiencias que se pueden vivir en Gambia. Te parecerá estar en la selva y podrás dar cacahuetes a los monos! Hay Yenas, pájaros, buitres...
Justo delante del African zoo está Jungle Man, te ofrecerá refrescos bien fríos, y podrás disfrutar de un buen rato charlando con él, y disfrutando del exótico lugar tomando un refresco. Le encanta poner las banderitas que le traen los clientes y te dará una agradable conversación.
Ojo si es época de lluvias! Ponte antimosquito porque te parecerá estar en la selva!

placeInfo.name: Abuko Nature Reserve
placeInfo.address: 15 Miles South of Banjul Kombo North District, Banjul Gambia

title: Take a guide for a small fee

placeInfo.name: Abuko Nature Reserve
placeInfo.address: 15 Miles South of Banjul Kombo North District, Banjul Gambia

title: Worth a visit - make sure you get a good guide.
text:
We had a mixed visit, in that there were no animals around (apart from one or two monkeys and some beautiful birds). However, we got lucky with our guide (sorry I can't remember his name) who was really informative and very knowledgable. He was able to talk passionately for the whole walk, which took a couple of hours. 

The animal orphanage is interesting, and you're guaranteed to see baboons, hyenas and lots and lots of vultures there - even if they are behind wire fences. 

Try to go if you're in the area - if only to support the business and the cause. Apparently early morning is the best time to see the animals.

placeInfo.name: Abuko Nature Reserve

De dieren zitten in hun natuurlijke omgeving (behalve uiteraard de dieren die in de kooien zitten) en het park doet enken aan het Gambia zoals het ooit geweest moet zijn voor het leeggeschoten is.
Je kan hiermdiverse apensoorten en vogels zien.

placeInfo.name: Abuko Nature Reserve
placeInfo.address: 15 Miles South of Banjul Kombo North District, Banjul Gambia

title: Interesting but very quiet
text:
We went on a day excursion from a cruise ship in Banjul.
The demo of palm tree climbing, juice tapping and the walk through the forest was interesting, but only worth doing on the basis of "we aren't likely to be coming to this part of The Gambia again". The constant demand for tips can be very wearing, though.

placeInfo.name: Abuko Nature Reserve
placeInfo.address: 15 Miles South of Banjul Kombo North District, Banjul Gambia

title: Hardly worth a visit
text: I made one of my Gambian friends take me here last year. There was little to see in return for a long walk in the heat. The guide insisted that we needed him, but gave hardly any information and neither the entry fee nor the guide's fee were cheap.

placeInfo.name: Abuko Nature Reserve
placeInfo.address: 15 Miles South of Banjul Kombo North District, Banjul Gambia

title: The Animal Orphanage needs some financial help
text: Second visit to this lovely natural place, great for birds and walking as mentioned previously - however the small animal orphanage as it is called within this place needs financial help from what I can see.  There are some Hyena's in a large cage however hidden next to the pelican is another cage with some very poorly looking Hyenas with sores etc, I'm not judging but from what I understand, this place needs some help to make sure the animals are cared for more, ie more food, medical help for animals and better quality of surroundings that they live in day after day.  The baboons could do with ropes and tyres hanging and things to amuse them and play with for example.  As its mainly tourists that visit this place, they could increase the entrance fee which could help. I have may ideas as to how this could be improved and would love to be able to help in someway.  That said, the wild monkeys are used to people and they will come and see you especially if you buy monkey nuts and will gently take them out of you hand which is a fantastic experience and one of the main reasons i viisit the place.

placeInfo.name: Abuko Nature Reserve
placeInfo.address: 15 Miles South of Banjul Kombo North District, Banjul Gambia

title: Great if you like wildlife & walking
text: Great chance to see some of The Gambia's wildlife but be prepared for 2hrs of walking in a wood/forest  If you go without a guide there are guides hanging around the entrance and they vary from very good to rubbish Unless you know the birds it can be difficult to chose a competent one.  I've had "guides" describe birds as little brown jobs and others that not only correctly identify but give you Latin names as well now that's just showing off!  Ask for a try before you buy  agree a price and get them to walk with you for 10 mins  and let them show you the birds you'll soon know what you've got  You can go it alone as it is difficult to get lost just follow the path but the good guide will show you so much more than you'll see going it alone and are well worth the 400D fee for their services

placeInfo.name: Abuko Nature Reserve
placeInfo.address: 15 Miles South of Banjul Kombo North District, Banjul Gambia

title: Rustig park, pinda's voeren aan apen.
text:
We went here after visiting the Serrekunda market and then you notice how peaceful it is
If you are there for birds you can get a guide with binoculairs. If you are not don't think they are freebies and say no.
After paying the fee and entering the park another man comes up with a donation form for maintenance on the park. They should include that in the ticket price and don't hassle on every opportunity.

We spotted some beautiful trees and we came across some monkeys. (we dont have the expert eye for birds so we didnt notice them) Also some termite hills.
Somewhere halfway there were some animals caged up. Baboons, 2 pelicans, a turtle and some hyena's.
The smaller monkeys run around and you can buy a bag of peanuts there to feed them. (about 25D for a bag) The bigger ones come pick them out of your hand and they can be quite greedy so you have to throw some around for the smaller ones to also enjoy some.

More walking ahead you come through a souvenir area.

This trip is for you if you like to walk a small hour and like to see some nature and animals.

Afterwards we also stopped at the nearby goat and sheep market.

placeInfo.name: Abuko Nature Reserve
placeInfo.address: 15 Miles South of Banjul Kombo North District, Banjul Gambia

title: Still as interesting as it was 40 years ago!
text: I lived in The Gambia in the 1970s, and spent every Sunday morning walking around the nature reserve, mainly birdwatching.  It is such a pleasure to return so many years later and find it almost unchanged, though sadly they need more funding to keep things going.  The highlight is watching the birds from the upstairs viewing area in the large building next to the lake, which also has crocodiles.  Take your binoculars and you will see so many different species!  Then the walk through the forest is fascinating, so many different trees, and with luck you will see plenty of monkeys, both the Callithrix and the Red Colobus monkeys.  They are easy to spot as they scamper through the trees, and trees with have fruit are often absolutely full of monkeys!  Unfortunately I didnt spot a monitor lizard on this visit, though there are many large lizards in the park, and snakes too, though the reptiles are much more active during the rainy season.  Halfway round the walk you reach the animal orphanage, which is a very sad sight with monkeys and baboons in enclosures, when they should be roaming wild.  Its all very dilapidated and makes you feel sorry for the animals.  At the end of the walk round there is a craft market, not very good I'm afraid, so it's better to hurry straight through!

placeInfo.name: Abuko Nature Reserve
placeInfo.address: 15 Miles South of Banjul Kombo North District, Banjul Gambia

title: ook beesten hebben recht op een fijn leven
text:
Dit park is de bezichtiging niet echt waard.
De natuur is oke met hier en daar een aap,  maar een groepje bavianen die in een veel te kleine kooi leven, waarvan er 1 ergens achter de pelikanen(die ook opgesloten zitten in een kooi zonder water) in een soort grote bench wordt gehouden omdat hij gek is geworden(volgens 1 van de gidsen)en twee groepen hyena's die ook zonder water in een smerige omgeving moeten leven is echt niet meer van deze tijd en dit mag gewoon niet.
Ga er niet heen en als je van dieren houd kom er dan niet eens in de buurt want het is hartverschurend.
ik ga zeker alles op alles zetten om deze dieren daar vandaan te halen.

placeInfo.name: Abuko Nature Reserve
placeInfo.address: 15 Miles South of Banjul Kombo North District, Banjul Gambia

title: Lovely nature reserve (its not a zoo!)
text:
Abuko is a wonderfully intact piece of tropical forest, amongst the otherwise heavily populated Serrekunda area. Some reviewers seem to be under the impression this a zoo, it's not! There is a small animal orphanage at one end of the reserve but its a desperately sad place and not a reason to visit.

I enjoyed wandering the narrow paths seeing birds, lizards and monkeys (you will see them if you walk slowly and quietly). The Darwin field centre is an excellent vantage point to see lots of wading birds and birds of prey as well as Nile Crocodiles.

The guides are knowledgeable and well worth taking along on an initial visit. I agree with the previous reviewer who advised taking water with you, it's quite a long way to do the full reserve circuit and the heat is sapping. The reserve doesn't get much funding so facilities are basic, but I loved it for being so quiet without lots of other people around.

I would recommend Abuko more to the serious nature lover who will get more from it than someone who expects to be entertained and see an animal every 2 minutes. For me, taking time was rewarded by getting to see amazing species like the Giant Kingfisher close up. I enjoyed it so much I actually went twice during my week in The Gambia.

placeInfo.name: Abuko Nature Reserve
placeInfo.address: 15 Miles South of Banjul Kombo North District, Banjul Gambia

title: Good for bird spotters
text: A pleasant outing, with lots of opportunities to spot fantastic bird life in the mature undergrowth. Our guide was knowledgeable but a bit uninspiring. We were sorry we didn't see crocs from the lookout point across the pool, and were disappointed and saddened by the dirty-looking 'animal orphanage' - even if they did have hyenas and pelicans. The refreshment point was a bit dull, leaving us exposed to the entreaties of the stallholder nearby.

placeInfo.name: Abuko Nature Reserve
placeInfo.address: 15 Miles South of Banjul Kombo North District, Banjul Gambia

title: A cancelled trip
text: I had booked Birds and Breakfast in England before I read a TripAdviser review which said it would be better to go to Abuku with a specialkist guide. The trip was cancelled so I followed advise from TripAdviser and had the most wonderful time using a local professional guide. I also discovered The University of Warwick (probably LifeSciences) have been working at Abuku for some years as part of a research programme. The little booklets are excellent and well worth the money.

placeInfo.name: Abuko Nature Reserve
placeInfo.address: 15 Miles South of Banjul Kombo North District, Banjul Gambia

title: Take a drink with you
text:
It's very hot take some water with you.
Lots to see as you walk with your guide.
Binoculars were a God send.

placeInfo.name: Abuko Nature Reserve
placeInfo.address: 15 Miles South of Banjul Kombo North District, Banjul Gambia

title: definitely worth a trip but probably just the once is enough...
text: we visited abuku in january with our 7 year old son, he loved it once we had actually found where the animals were, they keep the animals quite far from the entrance to the park, we declined the guide and walked a massive circle for nearly an hour to arrive back at the entrance having found nothing, we got our directions then took another 20 minute walk into the bush (get the guide at the entrance its worth it) we eventually came to 2 large enclosures one with lots of baboons going wild for the nuts we had purchased to feed them and another breed of monkey in the other and green monkeys all around us roaming free with the escapee (a baby baboon that refused to go back into the enclosure) i think there was around 5 different species of monkey/baboons in total as well as a monitor lizard we had passed on the way in.. after our talk from the keeper she guided us over to the final enclosure where the hyenas were having an afternoon nap, they were huge and there was also vultures in the enclosure, my boy was mesmerised,....... after a rest stop at the tuck shop for ice cold drinks we haggled ourselves a nice bargain on a wood carved ornament and headed our way to the exit... all in all was a very memorable day and so glad we went however it is not very interesting until the final moments of the park when u reach the animals.... am i glad i went? yes definitely and would recommend it too, but only once! so will i be returning? in a word,,, no.

placeInfo.name: Abuko Nature Reserve

Since the "president" Jammeh moved the most interesting animals to his private zoo in Kanilai, Abuko has lost many of its attractions. Nobody would officially admit, but this is what happened. So if you want to see a lion, better visit your local zoo :-(

title: Monkeys!!
text: Don`t miss this park on your trip to The Gambia-so much fun. The monkeys are very friendly-not vicious at all. They climb up you, sit on your shoulders etc as you feed them monkey nuts. So many monkeys!  Book the trip with the RSPB men on Bakau beach (under white umbrella by Calypso Restaurant) if you want to enjoy spotting the birds as well as well as knowledge of the local monkeys. If not then go with the tour guides opposite the Ocean Bay Hotel. They charged us 20 quid which included the taxi & full mornings entertainment plus relaxing time sat under the African sun shades on the beautiful beach next to the park.

title: Fantastic
text: Such a beautiful place to spend some time. We went in the early morning and only saw one other couple for the majority of the time we were there. However, on our way back out there were huge groups arriving. I would definately recommend going independantly with your own guide rather then with a tour company in a large group. We saw a huge variety of birds and ther were certainly some very enthusiastic bird watchers there with all the high tech binoculars, telescopes, cameras etc. We also saw a couple of crocodiles and lots of monkeys. Halfway round there is an animal sanctuary where they house animals that have been removed from locals who have bought them to entertain tourists for a charge. There was a very friendly monkey that sat on my knee and played with my hair. You can buy peanuts to feed to the monkeys. We absolutely loved our time here and spent a good 3 hours wandering around spotting monkeys and birds. From what I remember it cost approx 50d (£1) each to get in.

placeInfo.name: Abuko Nature Reserve

title: Peacful, beautiful and easy to see the birdlife
text: My guide, Francis Gomez, led me through the reserve pointing out the local birdlife.  Within minutes we had seen a dozen or more species I'd never seen before and over the three hours I was there, he was helpful, friendly and informative.  He helped me see the species unique to the site which I probably would have missed without him.  Admission to the reserve is very cheap but a guide will cost you about £20 upwards, depending how long you want to stay.  Apart from the birds, there's a chance you might spot a croc and definitely monkeys.

placeInfo.name: Abuko Nature Reserve
placeInfo.address: 15 Miles South of Banjul Kombo North District, Banjul Gambia

title: Beautiful but only for bird lovers
text:
We arrived at Abuko having heard and read quite a lot about it. It is better to come here early in the morning, not around 11am like we did since most of the animals are sheltering from the heat and crocodiles are swimming closer to the bottom of the pond.

The few monkeys we saw were not scared of humans, this is because they are used to humans feeding them. People saying it was great to feed wild monkeys probably have not been to a safari or national park before. Infact you are encouraged to buy peanuts for the monekys. And the zoo in the middle is apparently kept there so tourists can atleast see something in the reserve if nothing else. It is expensive to run these reserves and you can see that in the health of the hyenas and monkeys. The place was grand back in the day with lion(s) and other animals, when the founder Mr.Brewster was alive but now has deteriorated a little. The president's zoo is better funded and has more animals.

Saying that, we had a lovely walk around the area and saw some birds. Since we were not bird watchers or bird lovers, we just enjoyed the different varieties without knowing what they were :-)

placeInfo.name: Abuko Nature Reserve
placeInfo.address: 15 Miles South of Banjul Kombo North District, Banjul Gambia

title: Great for the nost part...till you get to the animals in cages...
text:
Although I thought Abuko was wonderful for the most part, (we saw a crocodile, a bushbuck and several species of monkeys and birds) I was dismayed to see the hyenas in captivity, also baboons and some other animals, all in cages. I was told that the baboons are orphaned (though it was a whole family), and also some of the other animals, but that the hyenas are just an exhibit. There also used to be a lion there but it escaped. Apparently they have links with the local zoo, and some of the animals live in captivity always. There is no need for this - visitors come to see wildlife in its natural state, not kept in a prison. The hyenas were pacing up and down i.e. exhibiting stereotypical behaviour, which was not good to see at all.

Also although there are notices up saying not to feed the wildlife however friendly it is, people (and one of the guides!) were openly feeding the monkeys peanuts, thus habituating the monkeys to humans, and causing them to lose their natural skills. Abuko should actively be fining people for doing this and the guides should be sufficiently educated so as not to do this. 

For this reason I have given this reserve a 3-star rating, otherwise it would be a 4 or 5.

placeInfo.name: Abuko Nature Reserve
placeInfo.address: 15 Miles South of Banjul Kombo North District, Banjul Gambia

title: The smell
text:
It is a long walk with little of interest from the main gate to the first lodge which is twinned with the University of Warwick (Birdwatching), A bit interesting as an alligator was watching a wading bird and we watched the alligator...yawn!!...  A short further walk through thicker overgrowth brings you to the heart of the reserve. Staff are always needing money to feed the animals... A very sad affair, as the main animals have allegedly been transported to the presidents old village  zoo.  You are left with the stench from 5 hyenas and 20 vultures who constantly watch the few monkeys that surround the area. 
There are a few captive monkeys to feed peanuts to if you want. Most fun was being professionally ambushed by the reserve monkeys on the way out who cleaned us of anything edible.  in conclusion..It was tired, the staff were tired, the animals looked tired...

placeInfo.name: Abuko Nature Reserve

title: Monkey Loving!
text:
I loved Abuko, it has a little something for everyone. 

It is quite a walk, the less mobile may want to give this a miss, but when you get to the end, the tamer monkeys are there to entertain
and steal the nuts you have just bought for them! Keep the plastic bag out of slight or they will grab at it! 

It was fantastic to feed wild monekys. This made the trip well worth it. 

If you drove to the park, like I did, as a bit of advice, when you get to the cafe, go visit the hyenas and stuff, but don't go through the past with the exit sign over it. Go back the way you came, otherwise you end up a 15 minute walk down a dusty busy road from where you first started!!
